title: Jaeseok Hwang
text:
Hi, Iâ€™m Jaeseok Hwang, a Ph.D.Â candidate in Agricultural and Consumer Economics (ACE)  at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC), with an expected graduation in May 2025. Over the past 5 years, I have gained extensive experience as a research assistant for the USDA NRCS-funded project, â€œData Intensive Farm Management.â€ 
In this role, I worked extensively with large-scale datasets, applying advanced data analytics and statistical techniques to address complex questions in farm management and productivity. During this time, I developed a deep expertise in designing and running machine-learning-based regression models to derive actionable insights from big data. My analytical toolkit includes a professional level of proficiency in R, which I use for most of my data processing, statistical modeling, and visualization tasks, as well as Python, which I employ as a versatile second option for complementary analysis and machine learning workflows.
This website highlights my research journey, showcasing programming code (R and Python via VS Code), summary of research outputs, and my individual research note reflecting my knowledge and skills.

title: Jaeseok Hwang

title: Risk-Managing Input Decisions under Price & Weather Risk

title: Projects
text:
Below are my current projects. Click a title to open the project site (built from the projectâ€™s own repository).














Value of Multiple Field Experimental Data (OFPE)


Pooling multi-field on-farm precision experiments to measure informational value and profit impact under weather uncertainty.




id


P01




repo


https://github.com/jaeseokh/value_multifield_ofpe















Input Decisions under Price & Weather Risk


Risk-aware fertilizer recommendations using Bayesian/ML with price-weather scenarios.

title: Jaeseok Hwang
Jaeseok Hwang
text: During my research journey in graduate school (MS and Ph.D.Â in Applied Economics), I developed a deep interest in Econometrics, Price Analysis, and Statistical Learning. This collection of essays showcases how I built my foundational knowledge and expanded my research focus. Please enjoy this material and feel free to contact me at jaeseok2@illinois.edu.

title: Welcome
text:
These notes collect concise explanations and examples on statistics and machine learning topics I often revisit in research and teaching.
Each section in the sidebar corresponds to a different topic area â€” click to open any note.



Basic Statistics â€“ probability, distributions, hypothesis tests

Bayesian Statistics â€“ posterior inference, MCMC, applied examples

Machine Learning â€“ regression, trees, ensemble methods





All examples reproducible in R or Python
Lightweight Quarto pages (HTML only)

title: â€”- Planâ€“Trackâ€“Feedback : monthly + weekly (one-chunk) â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
text:
â€”- Planâ€“Trackâ€“Feedback : monthly + weekly (one-chunk) â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
req <- c(â€œdplyrâ€,â€œtidyrâ€,â€œlubridateâ€,â€œggplot2â€,â€œgtâ€,â€œgooglesheets4â€,â€œstringrâ€) to_install <- req[!req %in% rownames(installed.packages())] if(length(to_install)) install.packages(to_install, quiet = TRUE) invisible(lapply(req, library, character.only = TRUE))


â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” 1) MONTHLY PLAN â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”


Edit these values each month right here
plan_title <- â€œStay Calm in Pocketâ€ plan_period <- â€œ3 years (Nov 2025 â€“ Nov 2028) of finding my real interest and talent.â€ principles <- c( â€œStick to the simple planâ€, â€œStart first â€“ finish it every day (no excuse)â€, â€œRelaxed but consistent workâ€ )
month_label <- â€œNovâ€“Dec 2025â€ focus_items <- c( â€œCPT Job & Defenseâ€, â€œGitHub Râ€“Python 3-chapter with webpageâ€, â€œEnsemble learning (stat inference) & Bayesian studyâ€, â€œPrice analysis (commodity market)â€, â€œEnglish (interview prep)â€ )


Render monthly plan blocks
cat(sprintf(â€œ## %sâ€, plan_title)) cat(sprintf(â€œ%sâ€, plan_period))
tibble(# = seq_along(principles), Principle = principles) |> gt() |> tab_header(title = md(â€œMonthly Principlesâ€)) |> tab_style(style = cell_text(weight = â€œboldâ€), locations = cells_column_labels(everything())) |> fmt_markdown(columns = everything())
cat(â€œâ€) tibble(Area = month_label, Focus = focus_items) |> mutate(Area = if_else(row_number()==1, Area, â€œâ€œ)) |> gt() |> tab_header(title = md(sprintf(â€Monthly Focus â€” %sâ€, month_label))) |> tab_style(style = cell_text(weight = â€œboldâ€), locations = cells_column_labels(everything())) |> cols_align(align = â€œleftâ€, columns = everything())


â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” 2) WEEKLY TRACK â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”


Keep a Google Sheet with columns:


Date | Academic | Career | Personal | Done (%) | Notes | Energy


Set sharing to: Anyone with link can view (or add your service account)
sheet_url <- â€œhttps://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/10_fOOT3k2c_W43h2iE8xDffhRs1spUNI_GDetKR8xLs/edit?gid=932499860#gid=932499860â€ # <<< EDIT: your Google Sheet URL >>>


Safe read; if the URL isnâ€™t set yet, skip gracefully
have_sheet <- grepl(â€œhttpâ€, sheet_url) if (have_sheet) { gs4_deauth() # uses public read if the sheet is shared to â€œAnyone with linkâ€ daily <- tryCatch( googlesheets4::read_sheet(sheet_url, sheet = 1, col_types = â€œDcccccnâ€), error = function(e) NULL ) } else { daily <- NULL }
if (is.null(daily)) { cat(â€œ> Weekly tracker will appear here once your Google Sheet URL is set and accessible.â€) } else {


Clean & metrics
daily <- daily |> rename( date = 1, academic = 2, career = 3, personal = 4, done_pct = 5, notes = 6, energy = 7 ) |> mutate( date = as.Date(date), done_pct = as.numeric(str_replace(done_pct, â€œ%â€,â€œâ€œ))/100 ) |> arrange(date)


Weekly summary (Monâ€“Sun)
weekly <- daily |> mutate(week = floor_date(date, unit = â€œweekâ€, week_start = 1)) |> group_by(week) |> summarise( days = n(), avg_done = mean(done_pct, na.rm = TRUE), green_days = sum(done_pct >= 0.9, na.rm = TRUE), yellow_days = sum(dplyr::between(done_pct, 0.6, 0.89), na.rm = TRUE), red_days = sum(done_pct < 0.6, na.rm = TRUE), avg_energy = mean(energy, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = â€œdropâ€ )


Show last 7 days table
cat(â€œ### Last 7 Days â€” Daily Logâ€) daily_tail <- tail(daily, 7) |> mutate(Done = scales::percent(done_pct, accuracy = 1)) |> select(date, academic, career, personal, Done, notes, energy)
daily_tail |> gt() |> tab_header(title = md(â€œDaily Plan â†’ Trackâ€)) |> cols_label( date = â€œDateâ€, academic = â€œAcademic ğŸ“â€, career = â€œCareer ğŸ’¼â€, personal = â€œPersonal ğŸ’ªâ€, notes = â€œNotes ğŸ—’â€, energy = â€œEnergy (1â€“5)â€ ) |> data_color( columns = â€œDoneâ€, colors = scales::col_bin( palette = c(â€œ#f87171â€, â€œ#fbbf24â€, â€œ#34d399â€), domain = c(0, 1), bins = c(0, 0.6, 0.9, 1.01) ) )


Weekly plot
cat(â€œ### Weekly Consistencyâ€) ggplot(weekly, aes(x = week, y = avg_done)) + geom_col() + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.9, linetype = 2) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1), limits = c(0,1)) + labs(x = â€œWeek (Mon start)â€, y = â€œAvg Done %â€, title = â€œWeekly Consistency Scoreâ€, subtitle = â€œDashed line at 90% targetâ€) + theme_minimal(base_size = 12)


Weekly summary table (most recent)
cat(â€œâ€) tail(weekly, 1) |> transmute( Week starting = week, Avg Done % = scales::percent(avg_done, 1), Green (â‰¥90%) = green_days, Yellow (60â€“89%) = yellow_days, Red (<60%) = red_days, Avg Energy = round(avg_energy,1) ) |> gt() |> tab_header(title = md(â€œThis Week at a Glanceâ€)) }
